<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 216, 304, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 352, 828, 368]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 495, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 447, 285, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 462, 907, 493]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 510, 590, 526]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 526, 606, 543]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 557, 606, 573]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 573, 756, 589]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 590, 440, 605]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 605, 907, 636]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
\(ABC\) is a uniform semicircular arc with diameter \(AC = 0.5 \text{m}\). The arc rotates about a fixed axis through \(A\) and \(C\) with angular speed \(2.4 \text{rad s}^{-1}\). Calculate the speed of the centre of mass of the arc.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 152, 94, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 163, 655, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 339, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
A uniform rod \(AB\) has weight \(6 \mathrm{N}\) and length \(0.8 \mathrm{m}\). The rod rests in limiting equilibrium with \(B\) in contact with a rough horizontal surface and \(AB\) inclined at \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. Equilibrium is maintained by a force, in the vertical plane containing \(AB\), acting at \(A\) at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to \(AB\) (see diagram). Calculate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 412, 151, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 412, 477, 430]]<|/det|>
the magnitude of the force applied at \(A\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 412, 918, 429]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 437, 151, 455]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 437, 608, 455]]<|/det|>
the least possible value of the coefficient of friction at \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 437, 918, 455]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 483, 94, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 483, 920, 516]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) is released from rest and falls vertically. At time \(t\) s after release \(P\) has speed \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). A resisting force of magnitude \(0.8 \nu \mathrm{N}\) acts on \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 530, 153, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 530, 556, 549]]<|/det|>
Show that the acceleration of \(P\) is \((10 - 4\nu) \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 530, 918, 549]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 561, 153, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 561, 421, 579]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\nu\) when \(t = 0.6\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 561, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 609, 94, 626]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 618, 737, 803]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 822, 920, 902]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is moving inside a smooth hollow cone which has its vertex downwards and its axis vertical, and whose semi-vertical angle is \(45^{\circ}\). A light inextensible string parallel to the surface of the cone connects \(P\) to the vertex. \(P\) moves with constant angular speed in a horizontal circle of radius \(0.67 \mathrm{m}\) (see diagram). The tension in the string is equal to the weight of \(P\). Calculate the angular speed of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 885, 920, 903]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected with speed \(30 \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) above the horizontal from a point \(O\) on horizontal ground. For the instant when the speed of \(P\) is \(17 \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) and increasing,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 114, 154, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 114, 761, 133]]<|/det|>
show that the vertical component of the velocity of \(P\) is \(8 \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) downwards,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 115, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 140, 153, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 140, 440, 158]]<|/det|>
calculate the distance of \(P\) from \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 140, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 186, 96, 204]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 196, 727, 395]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
A uniform lamina \(OABCD\) consists of a semicircle \(BCD\) with centre \(O\) and radius \(0.6 \mathrm{m}\) and an isosceles triangle \(OAB\), joined along \(OB\) (see diagram). The triangle has area \(0.36 \mathrm{m}^2\) and \(AB = AO\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 459, 154, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 459, 594, 477]]<|/det|>
Show that the centre of mass of the lamina lies on \(OB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 489, 153, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 489, 685, 507]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance of the centre of mass of the lamina from \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 535, 94, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
A light elastic string has natural length \(3 \mathrm{m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(45 \mathrm{N}\). A particle \(P\) of weight \(6 \mathrm{N}\) is attached to the mid-point of the string. The ends of the string are attached to fixed points \(A\) and \(B\) which lie in the same vertical line with \(A\) above \(B\) and \(AB = 4 \mathrm{m}\). The particle \(P\) is released from rest at the point \(1.5 \mathrm{m}\) vertically below \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 613, 153, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 613, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance \(P\) moves after its release before first coming to instantaneous rest at a point vertically above \(B\). (You may assume that at this point the part of the string joining \(P\) to \(B\) is slack.)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 644, 920, 663]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 675, 153, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 675, 920, 709]]<|/det|>
Show that the greatest speed of \(P\) occurs when it is \(2.1 \mathrm{m}\) below \(A\), and calculate this greatest speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 694, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 723, 151, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 723, 616, 740]]<|/det|>
Calculate the greatest magnitude of the acceleration of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 723, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
